Trellops User Guide

From initial setup to advanced mapping—everything you need to know.

Quick links: Getting Started · Dashboard Setup · Map View · Advanced Tips · Sharing

Getting Started & Privacy

How to Login

To use Trellops, simply log in with your existing Atlassian Trello user account. You will be asked to grant permission for Trellops to access your boards.

Privacy & Permissions

  • Local Storage: generally, Trellops follows a "Local First" policy. None of the information you enter is stored on our servers; everything stays local on your computer.
  • Read vs. Write Access: By default, Trellops only requires "Read" permissions to display your dashboard. However, if you wish to use the Map View to move cards between lists, you will be prompted to re-login and grant "Write" permissions.
  • Server Storage Exception: If you choose to share your configuration via a "Unique Link," we must store the technical skeleton of your layout (Board IDs, Block names) on our server to make the link work. No card content is stored.

Setting up your Dashboard

Once you select a board, head to the Settings menu. The interface is now split into three tabs: Dashboard, Map, and Other.

1. Creating Blocks (The Dashboard Tab)

A "Block" is a collection of list tiles that you group together. This allows you to organise your board logically (e.g., "Backlog," "Sprint," "Completed") rather than just alphabetically.

  • Create & Name: Create as many blocks as you need and give them meaningful names.
  • Hide/Show: You can temporarily hide a whole block from the main dashboard if you don't need to see it (e.g., hiding the "Done" column to focus on active work).

2. Configuring Tiles

Your Trello lists appear as "Tiles." You can now use the new Drag-and-Drop interface to organise them:

  • Assigning Lists: Drag a list from the "Unassigned" area into any Block you created.
  • Reordering: Want "Urgent" at the top? Simply drag the tile up or down to change the order.
  • Colour Coding: Click on any tile to assign a specific colour (e.g., Red for bugs, Green for finished items). If you don't choose a colour, we will assign a random one for you.

Using the Map View (New!)

Visualise your workload geographically. This feature automatically plots your cards onto a map based on their location data.

How it Works

Trellops looks for location data in your cards in two ways:

  1. Coordinates (Preferred): If a card has latitude/longitude stored in it, it plots instantly.
  2. Address Decoding: If no coordinates are found, Trellops reads the card's description field. If it finds an address, it uses the Google Maps service to find the location.
⚠️ Important Note on Speed: The Google Maps service limits requests to prevent abuse. If you open a map with 50 new addresses, it may take a moment to fully populate. We cache these locations on your browser, so the next time you load the map, it will be instant!

Map Features

  • Custom Icons: In the Map Settings tab, you can assign unique icons to different Blocks.
  • Icon Overrides: You can set specific icons to trigger based on Trello labels (e.g., a "Fire" icon for any card with a "Urgent" label).
  • Home Address: Set a "Home Address" to mark your HQ or office location on the map.
  • Move Cards: You can drag a card from one location to another list directly on the map (Requires "Write" permission).

Advanced Configuration & Filtering

Handling "Description Cards"

Sometimes, the first card in a Trello list isn't a task—it's a set of instructions or a header. This makes the total card count inaccurate. You can fix this in the Advanced Settings for that specific tile:

  • Don't Count First Card: Tells Trellops to ignore the first card so your total reflects actual work items.
  • Display as Description: You can choose to display the text of that first card on the dashboard tile, acting as a header or instruction for your team.

Dashboard Extras

  • Time Filtering: Use the filter menu to show only cards created "This Week" or "Last Week" to spot recent trends.
  • Digital Clock: Enable a large digital clock in the top-left corner—perfect for wall-mounted displays.
  • Themes: Manually switch between Light and Dark mode, or let it follow your system settings.
  • Clear Cache: If you need to reset everything, use the "Clear local storage" button in the "Other" settings tab. Warning: This erases all saved configurations.

Sharing Your Configuration

You can share your perfect dashboard setup with colleagues so they don't have to build it from scratch.

Option 1: Share via Link (New)

Click "Share Configuration" to generate a unique link. Send this to a colleague, and when they open it, their Trellops will load your exact layout (Board IDs, Blocks, and settings).

Option 2: Export to File

For a purely local options, you can "Export configuration to a file". Your colleague can then use the "Import" function to load that file directly into their browser.
